$$

= \frac{3}{\sqrt[4]{3}} \sqrt[4]{\frac{\sqrt{3}(ab+bc+ca)}{abc} + 6\sqrt{3}(a+b+c)} = \frac{3}{\sqrt[4]{3}} \sqrt[4]{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{abc} + 3\sqrt{3}[(a+b)+(b+c)+(c+a)]}
$$

Now, since $ab+bc+ca=1$, $a+b = \frac{1-ab}{c} = \frac{ab-(ab)^2}{abc}$. Similarly $b+c = \frac{1-bc}{a} = \frac{bc-(bc)^2}{abc}$.

And $c+a = \frac{1-ca}{b} = \frac{ca-(ca)^2}{abc}$. Hence, $\sqrt[4]{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{a} + 6\sqrt{3}b} + \sqrt[4]{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{b} + 6\sqrt{3}c} + \sqrt[4]{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{c} + 6\sqrt{3}a} \le \frac{3}{\sqrt[4]{3}} \sqrt[4]{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{abc} + \frac{3\sqrt{3}(ab+bc+ca - (ab)^2 - (bc)^2 - (ca)^2)}{abc}} = \frac{3}{\sqrt[4]{3}} \sqrt[4]{\frac{4\sqrt{3}}{abc} - \frac{3\sqrt{3}[(ab)^2 + (bc)^2 + (ca)^2]}}{abc}$.

Using Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality, $3((ab)^2 + (bc)^2 + (ca)^2) \ge (ab+bc+ca)^2 = 1$.

Hence $\sqrt[4]{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{a} + 6\sqrt{3}b} + \sqrt[4]{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{b} + 6\sqrt{3}c} + \sqrt[4]{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{c} + 6\sqrt{3}a} \le \frac{3}{\sqrt[4]{3}} \sqrt[4]{\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{abc}} = \frac{3^9}{\sqrt[4]{abc}}$.

This means we need only to prove that $\frac{3^8}{\sqrt[4]{abc}} \le \frac{1}{abc} \Leftrightarrow (abc)^3 \le \frac{1}{81\sqrt{3}}$.

Now, since $(abc)^2 = (ab)(bc)(ca) \le \left(\frac{ab+bc+ca}{3}\right)^3 = \frac{1}{27}$, we get $abc \le \frac{1}{3\sqrt{3}}$.

Hence, $(abc)^3 \le \frac{1}{81\sqrt{3}}$ which is what is required. For equality to hold, it requires $a=b=c$ and also

$w_1 + w_2 + \dots + w_m = 1$. Then

$(a_{1,1} + a_{1,2} + \dots + a_{1,n})^{w_1} (a_{2,1} + a_{2,2} + \dots + a_{2,n})^{w_2} \dots (a_{m,1} + a_{m,2} + \dots + a_{m,n})^{w_m} \\

Note that in case $n = 2$, $w_1 = w_2 = \frac{1}{2}$, we are back to the Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality.

• $0$ if $n=2$;
• $\frac{n(n-3)(n^2+6n-31)}{48}$ if $n$ is odd;
• $\frac{n(n^3+3n^2-52n+108)}{48}$ if $n$ is even and $n > 2$.

The result for $n=2$ is trivial. In the general case $n > 2$, label the players from 1 to $n$, and let $d_i$ be the number of games the $i$-th player has won. Then we note that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} d_i = C_2^n - n = \frac{n(n-3)}{2}$.

Observe that for a set of four players, if one of them beats everybody else, then the set is not harmonic. Also, there cannot be two players beating everybody else in the set simultaneously. Therefore, the number of harmonic sets is at most $C_4^n - \sum_{i=1}^n C_3^{d_i}$. The binomial function $f(x) = C_3^x$ is convex. Hence, applying Majorization Inequality, we get $\sum_{i=1}^n C_3^{d_i} \ge nC_3^{\frac{1}{n}\sum d_i} = nC_3^{\frac{1}{n}(n-3)}$ for odd $n$, so there can be at most $C_4^n - nC_3^{\frac{1}{n}(n-3)} = \frac{n(n-3)(n^2+6n-31)}{48}$ harmonic sets. Similarly, $\sum_{i=1}^n C_3^{d_i} \ge \frac{n}{2}C_3^{\frac{1}{n}(n-4)} + \frac{n}{2}C_3^{\frac{1}{n}(n-2)}$ for even $n$, so there can be at most $C_4^n - \frac{n}{2}C_3^{\frac{1}{n}(n-4)} - \frac{n}{2}C_3^{\frac{1}{n}(n-2)} = \frac{n(n^3+3n^2-52n+108)}{48}$ harmonic sets.

Now, we just have to show that these bounds are attainable. For odd $n$, it suffices to construct a scenario in which each player has won the same number (namely, $\frac{1}{2}(n-3)$) of games, and in which any set of four players in which nobody beats everyone else is harmonic. To do this, we assign the following:

• The game between players with consecutive numbers (including 1 and $n$) ends in a tie.

• If $i$ and $j$ are not consecutive with $i < j$, player $j$ beats player $i$ if $i$ and $j$ have the same parity, and player $i$ beats player $j$ if not.

We can check that the two conditions hold. Firstly, each player wins $\frac{1}{2}(n-3)$ games, as player $i$ beats players $i+3, i+5, \dots, n$ as well as all players whose numbers are smaller than and have the same parity as $i$. Secondly, let $S$ be a set of four players $A, B, C, D$ in which no player has beaten everyone else. We shall show that $S$ is harmonic.

Indeed, we first claim that no one in $S$ is beaten by everybody else in $S$. If $D$, say, is beaten by all the other three players, then the label for each of $A, B, C$ is either smaller than and has different parity as that of $D$, or larger than and has the same parity as that of $D$. Then the one with the largest label clearly beats everybody else in the set, which is a contradiction.

Now, since not all players in $S$ can be beaten by two other players, we may WLOG assume $A$ is not beaten by $B$ and $C$, while $A$ does not beat $D$. If $D$ beats both $B$ and $C$, then the game between $A$ and $D$ must end in a tie. Therefore, $A$ and $D$ have consecutive labels. As $D$ beats $B$, $B$ cannot be beaten by $A$.

We claim that $f(x, y)$ is a polynomial in $x$ and $y$ of degree at most $d$.

It is obvious that every such polynomial satisfies the desired condition. To prove the converse, let $f$ be a function satisfying the desired condition. Pick $(d+2)$ straight lines $\ell_1, \ell_2, \dots, \ell_{d+2}$ in $\mathbb{R}^2$ such that no two are parallel and no three are concurrent. Let the equation of $\ell_i$ be $h_i(x, y) = 0$, where $h_i$ is a linear polynomial.

For $i < j$, let $(a_{ij}, b_{ij})$ be the intersection of $\ell_i$ and $\ell_j$, and consider the polynomial

$$
\varphi(x, y) = \sum_{1 \le i < j \le d+2} f(a_{ij}, b_{ij}) \prod_{\substack{k=1 \\ k \ne i, j}}^{d+2} \frac{h_k(x, y)}{h_k(a_{ij}, b_{ij})}.
$$

It is easy to see that $\varphi(a_{ij}, b_{ij}) = f(a_{ij}, b_{ij})$ for all $i < j$, and that $\deg \varphi \le d$. We shall show that $\varphi(a, b) = f(a, b)$ for all $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$.

We first make an observation: if $\ell$ is a line such that $\varphi(a, b) = f(a, b)$ for at least $(d+1)$ points $(a, b)$ on $\ell$, then $\varphi(a, b) = f(a, b)$ for all points $(a, b)$ on $\ell$. Indeed, pick constants $A, B, C$ and $D$ such that $t \mapsto (At + B, Ct + D)$ parametrizes the line. Then, note that $\varphi(At + B, Ct + D) - f(At + B, Ct + D)$ is a polynomial of degree at most $d$, and that it vanishes at least $(d+1)$ points, so $\varphi(a, b) = f(a, b)$ for all $(a, b)$ on $\ell$.

Now, for a fixed $\ell_i$, note that $f(a_{ij}, b_{ij}) = \varphi(a_{ij}, b_{ij})$ for every $j \ne i$, so $f(a, b) = \varphi(a, b)$ for all points $(a, b)$ on $\ell_i$ from the claim. If $(c, d)$ is a point not lying on any $\ell_i$, then we can construct a line $\ell$ which passes through $(c, d)$, does not pass through any $(a_{ij}, b_{ij})$, and is not parallel to any $\ell_i$. Now $f(a, b) = \varphi(a, b)$ with $(a, b) = \ell_i \cap \ell$ for various $i$, so $f(a, b) = \varphi(a, b)$ for all $(a, b)$ on $\ell$. In particular, $\varphi(c, d) = f(c, d)$. This completes the proof. $\square$

We claim that the smallest *unnatural* case is $n = 6$. In the following, we use $(i, j)$ to mean the cell in the $i$th row and the $j$th column, and use $(i, j) - (i, k)$ to mean the consecutive cells from $(i, j)$ to $(i, k)$ inclusive (similar for $(i, j) - (k, j)$).

For $n = 2$, X and Y can play in any way and the natural loser X will lose.

For $n = 3$, Y is the natural loser and X has a winning strategy. In the first round, X marks (2, 2). WLOG Y has to mark (1, 1) - (1, 2). Then X can take (3, 1) - (3, 3).

For $n = 4$, Y has a winning strategy. In round 1, we may assume X chooses a cell in the upper left $2 \times 2$ corner. Then Y can mark 2 consecutive cells in the same $2 \times 2$ corner. This leaves 2 unoccupied rows as well as 2 unoccupied columns. WLOG we may assume X chooses certain cells from a row in round 3. Then there is at least one unoccupied row left, which can be marked by Y in round 4.

For $n = 5$, X has a winning strategy by first choosing (3, 3). WLOG, we may assume Y chooses 2 cells in the upper left $3 \times 3$ corner in the next round. Then X can always choose 3 consecutive cells from the same $3 \times 3$ corner. Again, there are at least 2 unoccupied rows and 2 unoccupied columns. For the same reason as the case $n = 4$, X can win the game.

The same trick no longer works for $n = 6$. The natural loser X can still win the game. We propose a winning strategy as follows. Firstly, X chooses (1, 1). WLOG assume Y chooses 2 cells $(i, j) - (i + 1, j)$ in the $j$th column in the next round.

*   If $j = 1$, X chooses $(3, 3) - (3, 5)$ in round 3. This blocks columns 3, 4, 5 and hence Y must mark at least one cell in column 2 or column 6 (but not both columns with obvious reason) in round 4. If some cells in column 2 (column 6 in the second case) is used, X can then take $(2, 6) - (6, 6)$ (correspondingly $(2, 2) - (6, 2)$) in round 5. Then all rows and columns have been used so that Y will lose.
*   A similar strategy works for cases $j = 2, 5, 6$. Y loses in all following subcases.
    -   For $j = 2$, X chooses $(3, 3) - (3, 5)$. In round 5, X should take $(2, 1) - (6, 1)$ or $(2, 6) - (6, 6)$, depending on column 6 is used or not.
    -   For $j = 5$, X chooses $(3, 2) - (3, 4)$. In round 5, X should take $(2, 1) - (6, 1)$ or $(2, 6) - (6, 6)$, depending on column 6 is used or not.
    -   For $j = 6$, X chooses $(3, 2) - (3, 4)$. In round 5, X should take $(2, 1) - (6, 1)$ or $(2, 5) - (6, 5)$, depending on column 5 is used or not.
*   If $j = 3, 4$ and $i = 1, 4, 5$, X can still choose $(3, 3) - (3, 5)$ in round 3.
    -   If Y chooses at least one cell in column 2 in round 4, X can then take $(2, 6) - (6, 6)$ in round 5. Y loses.
    -   If Y chooses at least one cell in column 6 in round 4, X can then take $(2, 2) - (6, 2)$ in round 5. Y loses.
    -   Suppose Y chooses $(2, 1) - (5, 1)$ in round 4. Next, X should take $(6, 2) - (6, 6)$ if row 6 is not used in round 2, or take $(1, 2) - (1, 6)$ otherwise. Y loses.
    -   Suppose Y chooses $(3, 1) - (6, 1)$ in round 4. Next, X should take $(2, 2) - (2, 6)$ if row 2 is not used in round 2, or take $(6, 2) - (6, 6)$ otherwise. Y loses.
*   If $j = 3, 4$ and $i = 2, 3$, X can take $(5, 3) - (5, 5)$ in round 3.
    -   If Y chooses at least one cell in column 2 in round 4, X can then take $(2, 6) - (6, 6)$ in round 5. Y loses.
    -   If Y chooses at least one cell in column 6 in round 4, X can then take $(2, 2) - (6, 2)$ in round 5. Y loses.
    -   If Y chooses $(2, 1) - (5, 1)$ in round 4, X can take $(6, 2) - (6, 6)$ in round 5. Y loses.
    -   Suppose Y chooses $(3, 1) - (6, 1)$ in round 4. Next, X should take $(2, 2) - (2, 6)$ if row 2 is not used in round 2, or take $(6, 2) - (6, 6)$ otherwise. Y loses.
    -   If Y chooses 4 consecutive cells in column 3, 4 or 5 in round 4, then the first 5 rows are all occupied. X can then take $(6, 2) - (6, 6)$ in round 5. Y loses.

In all cases, X can win the game when $n = 6$. This completes the proof. \u25a1

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have

$$
(a^2b + c^2d + ad^2 + cb^2)(a^2d + c^2b + ab^2 + cd^2) \geq (a^2\sqrt{bd} + c^2\sqrt{bd} + abd + CBD)^2 = \left(\frac{a^2 + c^2}{\sqrt{ac}} + abd + CBD\right)^2.
$$

Together with $a^2 + c^2 \geq \frac{1}{2}(a+c)^2 \geq (a+c)\sqrt{ac}$, we have

$$
(a^2b + b^2c + c^2d + d^2a)(ab^2 + bc^2 + cd^2 + da^2) \geq (a+c)^2(1+bd)^2.
$$

Due to symmetry, we also have

$$
(a^2b + b^2c + c^2d + d^2a)(ab^2 + bc^2 + cd^2 + da^2) \geq (b+d)^2(1+ac)^2.
$$

Multiplying these inequalities, we obtain

$$
(a^2b + b^2c + c^2d + d^2a)(ab^2 + bc^2 + cd^2 + da^2) \geq (a+c)(b+d)(1+ac)(1+bd)
$$

where $(1+ac)(1+bd) = 1+ac+bd+abcd = ac+bd+2$. The result follows readily.

For equality in the application of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we need $b = d$ and $a = c$. Note that the other inequalities also have these as equality. Together with $abcd = 1$, equality holds when $a = c = t$ and $b = d = \frac{1}{t}$ for some $t > 0$. $\square$

Suppose that

\[
a_2 b_2 n^2 + a_1 b_1 n + a_0 b_0 \mid (a_2^{2017n} + b_2)n^2 + (a_1^{2017n} + b_1)n + (a_0^{2017n} + b_0) \quad (1)
\]

We first claim that $a_0 = b_0 = 1$. Let $n$ be a large multiple of $a_0 b_0$. Since $a_0 b_0$ divides the left-hand side of (1), it also divides the right-hand side and hence $a_0 b_0 \mid a_0^{2017n} + b_0$. This implies $a_0 \mid b_0$ and $b_0 \mid a_0^{2017n}$. This shows $a_0, b_0$ have the same prime divisors. Thus, we can take a sufficiently large $n$ such that $a_0 b_0 \mid a_0^{2017n}$. This gives $a_0 b_0 \mid b_0$. The only possibility is $a_0 = 1$, which implies $b_0 = 1$.

Let $M$ be a sufficiently large integer and let $n_0$ be the product of all primes less than $M$. Choose any prime divisor $p$ of

\[
a_2 b_2 n_0^2 + a_1 b_1 n_0 + 1. \quad (2)
\]

Clearly, $(p, n_0) = 1$. Thus, $p \ge M$. In particular, we have $(p, a_1 a_2) = 1$ as $M$ is large.

Consider any $n$ such that $n \equiv n_0 \pmod{p}$. Then $p$ divides the left-hand side of (1). This gives

\[
p \mid (a_2^{2017n} + b_2)n_0^2 + (a_1^{2017n} + b_1)n_0 + 2. \quad (3)
\]

We choose $n$ such that $p-1 \mid n$. Such an $n$ exists by the Chinese remainder theorem. By Fermat's little theorem, we obtain $p \mid (1+b_2)n_0^2 + (1+b_1)n_0 + 2$. Taking the difference with (3), as $(p, n_0) = 1$, we get

\[
p \mid (a_2^{2017n} - 1)n_0 + (a_1^{2017n} - 1) \quad (4)
\]

for any $n \equiv n_0 \pmod{p}$. By taking $n \equiv 1 \pmod{p-1}$ and $n \equiv 2 \pmod{p-1}$ respectively, we have

\[
p \mid (a_2^{2017 \times 2} - 1)(a_1^{2017} - 1) - (a_1^{2017 \times 2} - 1)(a_2^{2017} - 1) = (a_1^{2017} - 1)(a_2^{2017} - 1)(a_2^{2017} - a_1^{2017}).
\]

Since $p \ge M$ is sufficiently large, the right-hand side must be 0. If one of $a_1, a_2$ is 1, then (4) implies both are equal to 1. If $a_1 = a_2$, then (4) implies $a_1 = a_2 = 1$ or $n_0 \equiv -1 \pmod{p}$.

We first consider the case $a_1 = a_2 = 1$. In that case, (1) becomes $b_2 n^2 + b_1 n + 1 \mid (1+b_2)n^2 + (1+b_1)n + 2$ so that $b_2 n^2 + b_1 n + 1 \mid n^2 + n + 1$. Note that $b_2 n^2 + b_1 n + 1 \ge n^2 + n + 1$. Thus, equality must hold and hence $b_1 = b_2 = 1$. One easily checks that $a_0 = a_1 = a_2 = b_0 = b_1 = b_2 = 1$ is a solution.

Next, it remains to consider the case $n_0 \equiv -1 \pmod{p}$. As $p$ divides (2), this yields $p \mid a_2 b_2 - a_1 b_1 + 1$. Since $p$ is large, we must have $a_2 b_2 - a_1 b_1 + 1 = 0$. Then (2) becomes $(a_1 b_1 - 1)n_0^2 + a_1 b_1 n_0 + 1 = (n_0 + 1)((a_1 b_1 - 1)n_0 + 1)$. Therefore, instead of choosing any prime $p$ dividing (2) at the beginning, we choose such a prime $p$ dividing $(a_1 b_1 - 1)n_0 + 1$. Using the same argument, we obtain either the same solution or $n_0 \equiv -1 \pmod{p}$. In the latter case, we find that $p \mid -(a_1 b_1 - 1) + 1$. Again, this forces $a_1 b_1 = 2$ as $p$ is large. Thus, $(a_1, b_1) = (1, 2)$ or $(2, 1)$. Also, $a_2 b_2 = a_1 b_1 - 1 = 1$ so that $a_2 = b_2 = 1$.

Now, by considering $n = 3$ in (1), we have $16 \mid 2(3)^2 + (a_1^{2017n} + b_1)(3) + 2$. As $a_1, b_1$ have different parities, the right-hand side is odd. This is impossible.

Therefore, the only solution is $a_0 = a_1 = a_2 = b_0 = b_1 = b_2 = 1$. $\square$

It is easy to check that both are solutions. Label the equation as follows.

\[
f(x + yf(x)) = f(x) + xf(y) \tag{1}
\]

Putting $x = 1$ in (1), we have

\[
f(1 + yf(1)) = f(1) + f(y). \tag{2}
\]

If $f(1) \neq 1$, then there exists $y \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $1 + yf(1) = y$. For this $y$, we obtain $f(1) = 0$. Then (2) becomes $f(y) = 0$ for all $y$, which is the first solution.

Now, we assume $f(1) = 1$. If $f(t) = 0$ for some $t \in \mathbb{R}$, by putting $x = t$ and $y = 1$ in (1), we obtain $t = 0$. This means $f(x) \neq 0$ for any $x \neq 0$. Putting $x = 1$ in (1), we have

\[
f(y + 1) = f(y) + 1. \tag{3}
\]

By induction we easily obtain $f(n) = n$ for any $n \in \mathbb{Z}$. Putting $x = -1$ in (1), we find that

\[
f(-y - 1) = -f(y) - 1.
\]

Using (3), we get $-f(y) = f(-y - 1) + 1 = f(-y)$. Replacing $y$ by $-y$ in (1), we have

\[
f(x - yf(x)) = f(x) - xf(y).
\]

Adding this to (1), we have

\[
f(x + yf(x)) + f(x - yf(x)) = 2f(x).
\]

For $x \neq 0$, we can replace $y$ by $\frac{y}{f(x)}$. This yields

\[
f(x + y) + f(x - y) = 2f(x). \tag{4}
\]

Note that this also holds when $x = 0$. Considering $x = y$, we find that

\[
f(2x) = 2f(x).
\]

Also, applying the substitution $a = x + y$ and $b = x - y$, equation (4) becomes

\[
f(a) + f(b) = 2f\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) = f(a+b).
\]

This shows $f$ satisfies the Cauchy equation. Thus, (1) can be simplified to

\[
f(yf(x)) = xf(y). \tag{5}
\]

Putting $y = 1$, we obtain $f(f(x)) = x$. Replacing $x$ by $f(x)$ in (5) and using $f(f(x)) = x$, we get

\[
f(xy) = f(x)f(y). \tag{6}
\]

It is well-known that a function $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ satisfying the Cauchy equation and (6) can only be the zero function or the identity function. Thus, another solution is $f(x) = x$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

For each colour $C_j$, there are $\binom{n-1}{2}$ triples of colours consisting of $C_j$ since we need to choose two more colours from the remaining $n-1$ colours. On the other hand, for every edge of colour $C_j$, there are $n-2$ triangles containing this edge since we need to choose one more vertex from the remaining $n-2$ vertices. Therefore, there are exactly

$$
\frac{1}{n-2} \binom{n-1}{2} = \frac{n-1}{2}
$$

edges of colour $C_j$. This implies $n$ must be odd.

We now provide a colouring for odd $n$. For any vertices $V_i$ and $V_j$, we use colour $C_r$ to colour the edge joining them where $r \equiv i + j \pmod{n}$. It suffices to show that for any distinct triples $r_1, r_2, r_3$, the system

$$
\begin{cases} i + j \equiv r_1 \pmod{n}, \\ j + k \equiv r_2 \pmod{n}, \\ k + i \equiv r_3 \pmod{n} \end{cases}
$$

has a unique solution in $i, j, k \pmod{n}$ such that $i, j, k$ are pairwise incongruent modulo $n$. Indeed, we readily find that

$$
 i \equiv 2^{-1}((i + j) - (j + k) + (k + i)) \equiv 2^{-1}(r_1 - r_2 + r_3) \pmod{n},
$$

and similarly $j \equiv 2^{-1}(r_1 + r_2 - r_3) \pmod{n}$ and $k \equiv 2^{-1}(-r_1 + r_2 + r_3) \pmod{n}$. These are incongruent because $r_1, r_2, r_3$ are incongruent modulo $n$. This completes the proof.

2. $n$ can be any odd integer larger than 1.

We use terminologies in graph theory. We need to colour all edges of the complete graph of $n$ vertices in $n$ colours $C_1, C_2, \dots, C_n$ such that for any three distinct colours, there exists a triangle whose edges are of these three colours.

Note that there are $\binom{n}{3}$ triangles as well as $\binom{n}{3}$ triples of colours. Therefore, the triangles and the triples of colours are in one-to-one correspondence.

Let $s = a + b + c$. Consider

$$
P(x) = (x - a)(x - b)(x - c) = x^3 - sx^2 + (ab + bc + ca)x - abc.
$$

Putting $x = s$, we obtain $(b+c)(c+a)(a+b) = (ab+bc+ca)s - abc$. Therefore, the given equation becomes

$$
(ab + bc + ca)s - abc + 2s^3 = 2 - 2abc.
$$

This is the same as $-s^3 - s^3 - (ab + bc + ca)s - abc = -2$, i.e. $P(-s) = -2$. In other words, we have

$$
(2a + b + c)(a + 2b + c)(a + b + 2c) = 2.
$$

(One can prove this by direct expansion.) By symmetry, it suffices to consider a few cases as follows.

* If $2a + b + c = 2$ and $a + 2b + c = a + b + 2c = 1$, adding these we obtain $4(a + b + c) = 4$. So we have $a + b + c = 1$, and hence $(a, b, c) = (1, 0, 0)$.

* If $2a + b + c = 2$ and $a + 2b + c = a + b + 2c = -1$, adding these we obtain $4(a + b + c) = 0$. So we have $a + b + c = 0$, and hence $(a, b, c) = (2, -1, -1)$.

* If $2a + b + c = -2$, $a + 2b + c = \pm 1$ and $a + b + 2c = \mp 1$, adding these we obtain $4(a + b + c) = -2$. There is no integer solution.

This shows the only solutions are $(a, b, c) = (1, 0, 0), (2, -1, -1)$ up to permutation.

By induction, we have shown that $f$ is completely multiplicative. Conversely, if $f$ is completely multiplicative, condition (iii) holds trivially.

Let $\mathcal{P}$ be the set of all primes from 1 to 100, and let $\mathcal{C} = S - (\mathcal{P} \cup \{1\})$ be the set of all composites. For any $n \in \mathcal{C}$, since $g(n), h(n) > 1$, we must have $f(g(n)), f(h(n)) > 1$. Therefore, $f(n) = f(g(n))f(h(n)) \in \mathcal{C}$. This implies $f(\mathcal{C}) = \mathcal{C}$. As $f(1) = 1$, by the bijective condition, we must have $f(\mathcal{P}) = \mathcal{P}$. Thus, it remains to assign distinct prime values to $f(p)$ for $p \in \mathcal{P}$. Afterwards we can easily compute $f(n)$ by the completely multiplicative condition, while the bijective condition is always satisfied.

Now, the only constraint is that $f(n) \in S$ for any $n \in S$. For example, since

\[
100 \ge f(64) = f(2)^6
\]

and $f(2) \ne 1$, we must have $f(2) = 2$. Similarly, by considering $f(81)$, we can prove that $f(3) = 3$. Next, since

\[
100 \ge f(75) = f(3)f(5)^2,
\]

we have $f(5) \le 5$, and hence $f(5) = 5$. Similarly, by considering $f(98), f(99)$ and $f(91)$, we can prove that $f(p) = p$ for $p = 7, 11, 13$.

Next, by considering $f(85)$ and $f(95)$, we can only prove that $f(17), f(19) \le 20$. Therefore, we have $\{f(17), f(19)\} = \{17, 19\}$. There is no further constraint on $f(17)$ and $f(19)$ since we can verify that $f(n) \in S$ for any $n$ being multiples of 17 or 19, as long as $f(17), f(19) \le 20$.

Similarly, by considering $f(92)$, we find that $f(23) = 23$.

By considering $f(87)$ and $f(93)$, we find that $\{f(29), f(31)\} = \{29, 31\}$.

By considering $f(74), f(82), f(86)$ and $f(94)$, we find that $37, 41, 43, 47$ can be mapped to any permutation of themselves.

Lastly, the images of $53, 59, 61, 67, 71, 73, 79, 83, 89, 97$ can be any permutation of themselves.

In view of the above arguments, we can choose the images within each group in an arbitrary way. Each choice corresponds to a unique function satisfying all requirements. Therefore, the number of such functions is

\[
2! \times 2! \times 4! \times 10! = 348364800.
\]

\]

\textbf{Claim.} A sequence \{$b_n$\} of positive real numbers is good if and only if the following conditions hold.

(i) There exists a constant $r > 0$ such that $b_{n+1} > rb_n$ for any $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$; and

(ii) there exists a positive integer $d$ such that $b_{n+d} > 2b_n$ for any $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

\textit{Proof.} Suppose \{$b_n$\} is good. Then we have $Nb_{n+1} > b_n$. So we can take $r = \frac{1}{N}$ for (i). Next, we take $d$ to be any integer larger than $2N^2 + 1$. Note that $Nb_{n+j} > b_1 + b_2 + \cdots + b_{n+j-1} > b_n$ for any $j \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. It follows that
\[
\begin{aligned}
b_{n+d} &> \frac{1}{N}(b_1 + b_2 + \cdots + b_{n+d-1}) \\
&> \frac{1}{N}(b_{n+1} + b_{n+2} + \cdots + b_{n+d-1}) \\
&> \frac{1}{N^2}(b_n + b_{n+1} + \cdots + b_n) \\
&= \frac{d-1}{N^2}b_n \\
&> 2b_n.
\end{aligned}
\]
This proves (ii).

Conversely, suppose (i) and (ii) hold. For any $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, we have
\[
\begin{aligned}
b_1 + b_2 + \cdots + b_n &= \sum_{j=1}^{d} (b_{n+1-j} + b_{n+1-j-d} + b_{n+1-j-2d} + \cdots) \\
&< \sum_{j=1}^{d} \left( b_{n+1-j} + \frac{1}{2}b_{n+1-j} + \frac{1}{2^2}b_{n+1-j} + \cdots \right) \\
&< \sum_{j=1}^{d} 2b_{n+1-j} \\
&< 2 \left( \sum_{j=1}^{d} \frac{1}{r^j} \right) b_{n+1}.
\end{aligned}

$$
AN^2 = AB^2 - BN^2 = AC^2 - CN^2 = AD^2 - DN^2.
$$

As $AB = AC = AD = 5$, we have $BN = CN = DN$ and so $N$ is the circumcentre of $\triangle BCD$. The circumradius of $\triangle BCD$ is given by the extended sine formula

$$
BN = \frac{CD}{2 \sin B} = \frac{5}{2 \cdot \frac{4}{5}} = \frac{25}{8}.
$$

The area of $\triangle BCD$ is $\frac{1}{2} \cdot BD \cdot MC = 12$. The volume of the pyramid is thus

$$
\frac{1}{3} \cdot 12 \cdot AN = 4 \cdot \sqrt{5^2 - \left(\frac{25}{8}\right)^2} = \frac{5\sqrt{39}}{2}.
$$

Let $u = \sqrt{2x+3}$. Then the equation becomes $2x^2 + 3u^2 = 7xu$, or $(2x-u)(x-3u) = 0$. Hence either $u = 2x$ or $x = 3u$.

* If $u = 2x$, we get $2x = \sqrt{2x+3}$. Squaring both sides gives $4x^2 = 2x + 3$, which leads to $x = \frac{1 \pm \sqrt{13}}{4}$.

* If $x = 3u$, we get $\frac{x}{3} = \sqrt{2x+3}$. Squaring both sides gives $\frac{1}{9}x^2 = 2x + 3$, which leads to $x = 9 \pm 6\sqrt{3}$.

Among these, the largest one is $x = 9 + 6\sqrt{3}$. One can check that in this case

\[
3u = \sqrt{18x + 27} = \sqrt{189 + 108\sqrt{3}} = \sqrt{(9 + \sqrt{108})^2} = x
\]

and so such x satisfies the original equation, which is therefore the largest real root of the equation.

$$

Note that we can always write

$$
f(x) = c_p \binom{x}{p} + c_{p-1} \binom{x}{p-1} + \cdots + c_1 \binom{x}{1} + c_0
$$

for some rational coefficients $c_0, c_1, \dots, c_p$, since $\binom{x}{p}, \binom{x}{p-1}, \dots, \binom{x}{0}$ have different degrees. By putting $x = 0$, we get $c_0 = f(0) \in \mathbb{Z}$. By putting $x = 1$, we get $c_1 + c_0 = f(1) \in \mathbb{Z}$, and hence $c_1 \in \mathbb{Z}$. Similarly, by putting $x = 2, 3, \dots, p$, we find that all $c_j$'s are integers. Conversely, if all $c_j$'s are integers, it is obvious that $f(m) \in \mathbb{Z}$ for any $m \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Now, putting $x = p + 1$ and using $\binom{p+1}{k} = \binom{p}{k} + \binom{p}{k-1}$, we obtain

$$
f(p+1) - f(1) = \sum_{k=0}^{p} c_k \binom{p+1}{k} - (c_1 + c_0) = \sum_{k=1}^{p} c_k \left[ \binom{p}{k} + \binom{p}{k-1} \right] - c_1.
$$

Since $p \mid \binom{p}{r}$ whenever $1 \le r \le p-1$, we have

$$
f(p+1) - f(1) \equiv c_p \pmod{p}.
$$

Therefore, $p \mid f(p+1) - f(1)$ if and only if $p \mid c_p$. This shows $f(x)$ can be any polynomial of the form mentioned at the beginning.

Similarly, we count the number $N_2$ of good subsets containing a particular odd number. Suppose such a good subset contains $i \ge 2$ even numbers and $j$ more odd numbers. Then we need $i \ge j + 2$. This implies

$$
\begin{align*} 
N_2 &= \sum_{i=2}^{n} \sum_{j=0}^{i-2} \binom{n}{i} \binom{n-1}{j} \\
&= \sum_{i=2}^{n} \sum_{k=n+1-i}^{n-1} \binom{n}{i} \binom{n-1}{k} \\
&= \sum_{i+k \ge n+1} \binom{n}{i} \binom{n-1}{k} \\
&= \sum_{m=n+1}^{2n-1} \binom{2n-1}{m} \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left( \sum_{m=0}^{2n-1} \binom{2n-1}{m} - \binom{2n-1}{n-1} - \binom{2n-1}{n} \right) \\
&= 2^{2n-2} - \binom{2n-1}{n}.
\end{align*}
$$

Now, the sum of all the elements in all the good subsets of $S$ is

$$
\begin{align*} 
N_1(2+4+\cdots+2n) + N_2(1+3+\cdots+(2n-1)) \\
&= 2^{2n-2} \cdot n(n+1) + \left[ 2^{2n-2} - \binom{2n-1}{n} \right] \cdot n^2 \\
&= 2^{2n-2}(2n^2+n) - n^2 \binom{2n-1}{n}.
\end{align*}
$$

A subset $T$ of $S$ is called a *bad* subset if in $T$ the number of odd elements is greater than the number of even elements. A subset of $S$ is neither good nor bad if it has exactly $k$ odd elements and $k$ even elements for some $k = 0, 1, \dots, n$. Since there are $n$ odd elements and $n$ even elements in $S$, the number of subsets which are neither good nor bad is

$$
\sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k}^2 = \binom{2n}{n}
$$

by Vandermonde's identity.

Now, by symmetry, the number of good subsets is the same as the number of bad subsets. As there are $2^{2n}$ subsets of $S$ in total, the total number of good subsets is

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left[2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}\right] = 2^{2n-1} - \frac{1}{2}\binom{2n}{n}.
$$

$$
N_1 = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \sum_{j=0}^{i} \binom{n-1}{i} \binom{n}{j} = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \sum_{k=n-i}^{n} \binom{n-1}{i} \binom{n}{k} = \sum_{i+k \ge n} \binom{n-1}{i} \binom{n}{k}

by using the change of variable $k = n-j$. Note that this is equal to the sum of coefficients of all $x^m$ with $m \ge n$ in $(1+x)^{n-1}(1+x)^n = (1+x)^{2n-1}$. Thus, we obtain

\]

It suffices to show $(2\sqrt{ab}+c+1)(a+b+c+1) \ge 13ab$. Indeed, since $a+b \ge 2\sqrt{ab}$, we only need to prove

\[
2\sqrt{ab} + c + 1 \ge \sqrt{13ab}.
\]

As $c \ge b \ge a$ and $abc = 1$, we have $c \ge 1$. Therefore, we have $\sqrt{c}(c+1) \ge 2$. This implies

\]

It remains to prove $8t^4 + 20t^3 - 18t^2 - 9t + 8 \ge 0$ for $t > 0$. Indeed, the left-hand side is equal to

The first term is nonnegative since $t > 0$. Since $663^2 - 4(524)(256) < 0$, the last term is nonnegative. This proves the inequality and we are done.

**Proof.** Consider a graph as follows. Let the vertices be the $2n$ special cells. For each row and each column, we draw an edge between any pair of adjacent vertices. If there are $r_1, r_2, \dots, r_n$ vertices in the $n$ rows, then the number of horizontal edges is at least

$$
(r_1 - 1) + (r_2 - 1) + \dots + (r_n - 1) = 2n - n = n.
$$

Similarly, there are at least $n$ vertical edges. Thus, we have $2n$ edges in total. It is well-known that a graph with $2n$ vertices and at least $2n$ edges consists of a cycle.

This cycle in the graph corresponds to a 'cycle' of cells in the table. If this cycle consists of three consecutive cells $(i, j), (i, j'), (i, j'')$ in the same row, then we can remove $(i, j')$ to shorten the cycle. We can do the same thing for consecutive cells in the same column. Eventually, we obtain a cycle such that the cells alternately lie in the same row and in the same column, which is exactly our claim. $\square$

Now, we choose a cycle of special cells as given by the claim. Note that the value

$$
(a_{i_1 j_1} + a_{i_2 j_2} + \dots + a_{i_s j_s}) - (a_{i_1 j_2} + a_{i_2 j_3} + \dots + a_{i_s j_1}) \quad (1)
$$

is unchanged after any operation. Indeed, if we add $x$ to row $i$, and there are $m$ indices among $i_1, i_2, \dots, i_s$ equal to $i$, then the value is changed by $+mx - mx = \pm 0$. The same holds for column operations. Since all the entries involved eventually become 0, the initial value of (1) must be 0.

For even $n$, suppose $a_j + \frac{(-1)^j}{a_j} = b_j$ for $1 \le j \le n$, where $\{b_j\}$ is a permutation of $\{a_j\}$. The relation can be rewritten as

$$
a_j^2 - a_j b_j = (-1)^{j+1}.
$$

Summing over all $j$'s, we obtain

$$
\sum_{j=1}^{n} (a_j^2 - a_j b_j) = 0
$$

since $n$ is even. As $\{b_j\}$ is a permutation of $\{a_j\}$, this implies

$$
\frac{1}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{n} (a_j - b_j)^2 = 0.
$$

Hence, we must have $a_j = b_j$, which is impossible since $a_j + \frac{(-1)^j}{a_j} = b_j$. Therefore, there is no such sequence.

For $n=1$, we need $a_1 - \frac{1}{a_1} = a_1$, which is impossible.

So it remains to show that such a sequence exists when $n > 1$ is odd. First we construct a sequence $a_1, a_2, \dots, a_{n+1}$ such that $a_1 = 1 + x$ with $x > 0$, and

$$
a_{j+1} = a_j + \frac{(-1)^j}{a_j}
$$

for $1 \le j \le n$. It suffices to show $a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n$ are pairwise distinct, and choose $x$ such that $a_{n+1} = a_1$.

Note that

$$
a_{j+2} = a_{j+1} + \frac{(-1)^{j+1}}{a_{j+1}} = a_j + \frac{(-1)^j}{a_j} + (-1)^{j+1} \left( a_j + \frac{(-1)^j}{a_j} \right)^{-1} = a_j + \frac{1}{a_j^3 + (-1)^j a_j}.
$$

For odd $j$, since $a_1 > 1$, we can prove inductively that $a_{j+2} > a_j > 1$. Also, for even $j$, since $a_2 = a_1 - \frac{1}{a_1} > 0$, we can prove inductively that $a_{j+2} > a_j > 0$.

Therefore, if we can prove that $a_{n+1} = a_1$, then we have

$$
0 < a_2 < a_4 < \dots < a_{n+1} = a_1 < a_3 < \dots < a_n,
$$

and so all terms are pairwise distinct positive real numbers.

By using the recurrence relation, it is obvious that $a_{n+1}$ is a continuous function of $a_1$. When $a_1$ goes to 1, we have

$$
a_{n+1} - a_1 \ge a_4 - a_1 = a_2 + \frac{1}{a_2^3 + a_2} - a_1 \to \infty
$$
since $a_2 \to 0$. This shows $a_{n+1} - a_1 > 0$ for some $x$.

On the other hand, for even $j$, as $a_j \ge a_2 = 1+x - \frac{1}{1+x} = \frac{2x+x^2}{1+x} > x$, we have

$$
a_{j+2} = a_j + \frac{1}{a_j^3 + a_j} < a_j + \frac{1}{x^3},
$$

and hence $a_{n+1} < a_2 + \frac{n-1}{2x^3}$ by summing over all $j$'s. It follows that

$$
a_{n+1} - a_1 < a_2 + \frac{n-1}{2x^3} - a_1 = \frac{n-1}{2x^3} - \frac{1}{1+x} = \frac{(n-1) + (n-1)x - 2x^3}{2x^3(1+x)} < 0
$$

for sufficiently large $x$.

Now, by the intermediate value theorem, there exists $x > 0$ such that $a_{n+1} = a_1$. So we are done.
